docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 8 REFERRED QUESTIONS OF LAW AND STATED CASES [rr 6.33–6.41]

heading.title: DIVISION 8 REFERRED QUESTIONS OF LAW AND STATED CASES [rr 6.33–6.41]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 8 REFERRED QUESTIONS OF LAW AND STATED CASES [rr 6.33–6.41]

leg:heading.title: REFERRED QUESTIONS OF LAW AND STATED CASES [rr 6.33–6.41]

p.text: [Div 8 insrt Amendment 13 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[2], effective 5 April 2007]
In this Division:
, in relation to a referred question of law or stated case, means the proceedings (if any) in which the question or case has arisen.
means a question of law or stated case that has been referred to the Supreme Court for determination.
means the court or other authority by which a question of law or stated case is referred to the Supreme Court for determination.
A reference in this Division to the Supreme Court includes a reference to the Court of Appeal where the proceedings concerned are assigned to or in the Court of Appeal.
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[4], effective 8 August 2008]
This Division applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court for an order with respect to a referred matter under a legislative provision, including (but not limited to) the following provisions:
Administrative Decisions Tribunal Act 1997, section 79A , 118 or 118D ,
Constitution Further Amendment (Referendum) Act 1930, section 28 ,
Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001, section 66 ,
Powers of Attorney Act 2003, section 39 ,
Real Property Act 1900, section 123 or 124 ,
This Division also applies by force of rules 12.1A and 15.1 of the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 to questions referred to the Supreme Court under the following Commonwealth legislation:
Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 2001, section 61 ,
Corporations Act 2001, section 659A .
[r 6.34 subst Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 8 August 2008 ; am Amendment 24 of 2009 r 2 and Sch 1[7], effective 6 March 2009]

level.toc-caption: [6.34.5] Stated cases and referred questions of law

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.34.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.34.
(NSW) Administrative Decisions Tribunal Act 1997 118, 119, ss 79A.
(NSW) Constitution Further Amendment (Referendum) Act 1930 s 28.
(NSW) Powers of Attorney Act 2003 s 39.
(NSW) Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 s 66.
(NSW) Real Property Act 1900 ss 123, 124.

heading.title: Stated cases and referred questions of law

p.text: Historically many statutory provisions authorised a “stated case” procedure. Typically the statutory “stated case” procedure afforded either a right of appeal from, or a power of referral by, subordinate courts and tribunals: Frost v Amaca Pty Ltd (2004) 61 NSWLR 159; [2004] NSWCA 358; BC200406560 at [26]–[29] (the Dust Diseases Tribunal has no power to state a case to the Supreme Court). Most usually the power under the statutory stated case procedure was restricted to the determination of questions of law. Where the stated case procedure was available, a party could request that a case be stated to the court, at any time prior to the entry of orders in the proceedings in the subordinate forum: Environment Protection Authority v Land and Environment Court of New South Wales (2004) 134 LGERA 140; A Crim R 198; [2004] NSWCA 50; BC200401386 .

The stated case procedure has often been criticised. It has been described as “a cumbersome and often unsatisfactory means of bringing a matter up for consideration on appeal”: Collins v State Rail Authority of New South Wales (1986) 5 NSWLR 209 at 211; (1988) 34 A Crim R 31 ; per Street CJ. Even more pejorative is the complaint that the procedure by way of stated case is generally not satisfactory for determination of very difficult questions and except in very simple cases is artificial, time-consuming and expensive: White v Ridley (1977) 140 CLR 342 at 362; 27 ALR 661 at 678 per Murphy J; see also Brisbane City Council v Valuer-General (Qld) (1978) 140 CLR 41 at 61; 21 ALR 607 at 623; BC7800070 . The principal basis of these criticisms seems to be related to the fact that the court is required to deal with the stated case without the benefit of findings and analysis by the inferior court or tribunal.

Because of these kinds of criticisms, and the inherent difficulty of the distinction between questions of fact and questions of law which stated cases typically involve, there has been a marked decline in the number of statutory provisions permitting the use of stated cases, as distinct from conferring rights of appeal. As at 1 January 2009, the relevant statutory provisions permitting subordinate tribunals to state cases to the Supreme Court were largely confined to the provisions identified in UCPR r 6.34 . These involve either the referral of questions of law (under the Administrative Decisions Tribunal Act 1997 ss 79A , 118 and 119 ; the Constitution Further Amendment (Referendum) Act 1930 s 28 ; the Powers of Attorney Act 2003 s 39 and the Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 s 66 ) or the referral of a stated case (under the Real Property Act 1900 ss 123 and 124 ).
[subr (1) rep Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 8 August 2008]
The originating process:
in the case of proceedings to which the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 apply, must be in the form of the originating process prescribed by rule 2.2 of those rules, and
in any other case, must be in the form of a summons.
The referred matter:
must be in the form of a special case, and
must be filed with the originating process.
The originating process must join as defendants (or as respondents where the proceedings are in the Court of Appeal):
if the referred matter has arisen in original proceedings, all of the parties to the original proceedings, or
in any other case, all of the persons who may be directly affected by the Supreme Court’s determination of the referred matter.
[subr (4) am Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[7], effective 8 August 2008]
In the case of proceedings under section 123 of the Real Property Act 1900, the originating process must also join the Registrar-General as a defendant.
The Supreme Court may order that such other persons as it considers appropriate be joined as defendants (or as respondents where the proceedings are in the Court of Appeal).
[subr (6) am Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[7], effective 8 August 2008]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.36] r 6.36 Form of special case (cf Federal Court Rules Order 50, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Form of special case (cf Federal Court Rules Order 50, rule 1 )

p.text: A special case:
must be divided into consecutively numbered paragraphs, and
must state concisely the questions to be decided and the facts from which those questions arise, and
must annex all documents necessary to enable the Supreme Court to decide those questions.

level.toc-caption: [6.36.5] Question to be decided in “special” case

heading.title: Question to be decided in “special” case

p.text: The questions to be determined by the Supreme Court on the “special” case (ie, the referred proceedings or the stated case) should be set out clearly. The question must not be put in the form of seeking an advisory interpretation of legislation: Pearce v FCT (1978) 20 ALR 354; 8 ATR 795 ; see also Thompson v Riley McKay Pty Ltd (No 2) (1980) 29 ALR 267; 42 FLR 279; (1980) ATPR ¶40–152 . If the “special” case is in the nature of an appeal, the statement should set out clearly the grounds on which it is contended that any earlier decision is erroneous — although a mere failure to formulate those grounds clearly will not necessarily prevent the court from considering substantial questions of law on appeal: Bennet v Dickson (1947) 64 WN (NSW) 23 ; Jones v Cunningham (1949) 66 WN (NSW) 44. A note on the proper drafting of a case stated appears in (1991) 65 ALJ 418.

The questions to be decided by the court on a stated case may vary depending upon the construction of the relevant statute. The question may be one of law, one of mixed law and fact or one of fact. Accordingly, the contents of a stated case in complying with the requirements of UCPR 6.36(b) to “state concisely “the facts from which those questions arise” and the requirement in UCPR 6.36(c) to annex “all documents necessary to enable the Supreme Court to decide those questions” will vary according to the nature of the questions.

At least in those instances where the “special” case is in the nature of an appeal, the tribunal stating the case ought make specific findings of fact on the disputed issues: Glover v MacDougall [1976] 2 NSWLR 359 ; McNeall v Croker (1939) 56 NSWLR 57; (1939) 56 WN (NSW) 57 ; Hale v Kaffer (1940) 58 WN (NSW) 1 ; Dennis v Watt (1942) 59 WN (NSW) 204 ; Johanson v Dixon (No 2) [1978] VR 243 . The “special” case should clearly set out all the facts found by the tribunal in which the original proceedings were conducted and that are relevant to the question posed for determination in the case: McNeall v Croker (1939) 56 NSWLR 57; (1939) 56 WN (NSW) 57 ; Glover v MacDougall [1976] 2 NSWLR 359 ; Johanson v Dixon (No 2) [1978] VR 243 and Murphy v O'Reilly (SC(NSW), Yeldham J 15 September 1978, unreported). Those findings should be specified in a logical, usually chronological, order: Ex parte Benson; Re Harris (1949) 66 WN 18; Hale v Kaffer (1940) 58 WN (NSW) 1 ; Dennis v Watt (1942) 59 WN (NSW) 204.

In a case where the question to be determined is one of ultimate fact or of mixed fact and law the matters stated in the case cannot be limited to ultimate facts. They must include all matters which are relevant to the proof or disproof of the question in issue: Zukerman v Law Society of New South Wales (1986) 5 NSWLR 292 . Nevertheless, a stated case should not set out the whole of the evidence in the proceedings — unless it is contended that there was no evidence to support a particular finding: Orange City Council v Canobolas Shire Council (1969) 91 WN (NSW) 676 .

It is customary to annex the reasons for judgment to the special case and convenient to do so, to enable the matter to be properly understood. If the reasons reveal an error of law the court is entitled to correct that error, even if it would not otherwise have appeared from the special case. However, it is impermissible to regard the reasons for judgment as a statement of the facts or as a statement of the evidence: Brisbane City Council v Valuer-General (Qld) (1978) 140 CLR 41 at 58; 21 ALR 607 at 621; BC7800070 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.37] r 6.37 Procedure for preparing special case (cf Federal Court Rules Order 50, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Procedure for preparing special case (cf Federal Court Rules Order 50, rule 2 )

p.text: In the case of a referred matter that has arisen in original proceedings, a special case:
must be prepared in draft by the party having the conduct of the original proceedings in consultation with the other parties to those proceedings, and
must be settled by the referring body,
unless the referring body otherwise directs.
In the case of a referred matter that has arisen otherwise than in original proceedings, a special case must be prepared:
in the case of proceedings under section 123 of the Real Property Act 1900, by the applicant referred to in that section, or
in any other case, by the referring body.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.38] r 6.38 Conduct of proceedings (cf Federal Court Rules Order 50, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Conduct of proceedings (cf Federal Court Rules Order 50, rule 4 )

p.text: This rule applies to any proceedings with respect to a referred matter that has arisen in original proceedings.
Subject to rule 7.8 , the party at whose instance the matter has been referred is to have the conduct of the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.39] r 6.39 Insufficient case (cf SCR Part 32, rule 7)

p.text: This rule applies to any proceedings in which it appears to the Supreme Court that a special case:
does not sufficiently state the questions to be decided or the facts from which those questions arise, or
does not annex sufficient documents,
to enable it to determine the proceedings.
In these circumstances, the Supreme Court:
may add to or otherwise alter the special case, or
may send the special case back to the referring body for the purpose of addition or other alteration.
[repealed]
[subr (2) am Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[8]–[9], effective 8 August 2008]

level.toc-caption: [6.39.5] Insufficient case and powers of the Supreme Court

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.39.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.40.

heading.title: Insufficient case and powers of the Supreme Court

p.text: If the case is not properly and specifically stated, particularly in relation to factual findings to be made in the original proceedings; it will ordinarily be appropriate (subject to the powers conferred by UCPR r 6.40 ) for the case to be remitted to the judge at first instance with a request that it be re-stated: Mitchell v Noble (1980) 7 NTR 19. The exercise of the powers conferred by UCPR r 6.40 may permit the Supreme Court to make additional findings of fact. But it will not usually be open to review findings of fact made in the original proceedings, especially where the findings are based on an assessment of the credibility of a witness in those proceedings: see Johanson v Dixon (1979) 143 CLR 376; 25 ALR 65 .
The Supreme Court may draw from the facts stated in, and the documents annexed to, a special case any inference, whether of fact or law, that might have been drawn from them if proved at a trial.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.41] r 6.41 Referred matters under section 28 of the Constitution Further Amendment (Referendum) Act 1930

leg:heading.title: Referred matters under section 28 of the Constitution Further Amendment (Referendum) Act 1930

p.text: This rule applies to any question that is referred to the Supreme Court under section 28 of the Constitution Further Amendment (Referendum) Act 1930.

Proceedings on the question are commenced by transmission to the Prothonotary of a statement of the question, as provided for in section 29 of the Constitution Further Amendment (Referendum) Act 1930.
On receiving the statement, the Prothonotary must list the matter before a Judge of the Supreme Court for directions.
The Supreme Court may give all such directions as are necessary for the conduct and disposal of the proceedings on the question.
Rules 6.35–6.40 do not apply to the proceedings on the question.
